turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in Wise v. Lipscomb.
Mr. Werner, I think you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
I am Joseph Werner, counsel for petitioners in this case, the Mayor and City Council of the City of Dallas.
This is a civil rights case in which Negro voters of the City of Dallas challenge the all at-large system of electing the City Council in Dallas.
The District Court held at that that all at-large system was unconstitutional and that it denied Negro voters equal protection.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Was that the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not the Fifteenth Amendment?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: No, sir.
No consideration.
It was alleged that there was a violation of the Fifteenth Amendment

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But the grounds for the Court's decision was the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In so far as the Dallas electoral system, discriminated racially, is that it?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: There was no finding of any violations of Reynolds v. Sims in any of this --

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: No, sir, there is no question of Sims, since it was a purely at-large system in the beginning.
There is no question of a numerical imbalance.
It was a White versus register type dilution problem.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It is not a Fifteenth Amendment decision?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But there was no finding of any constitutional violation here, was there, in the at-large system?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.
We started out with all eleven members of the council elected at-large city wide.
The District Court found that that system was unconstitutional and that it denied equal protection to the Negro voters.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And you are not really released and this case does not involve that issue, does it?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: No, sir.
The issue --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have a totally new structure now.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But they did not find a one man, one vote violation?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: No sir.
As I said, because it was purely at-large in the beginning and there was no possibility of a numerical imbalance.
The District Court, after it held the previous system unconstitutional, gave the City of Dallas and the City Council an opportunity to come up with a plan to remedy this constitutional violation.

The Court held hearing subsequently in which it received this eight/three plan which was generated by the City Council and this plan involves the election of eight of the eleven council members from single member districts and the election of the remaining three members at-large, city wide.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Werner?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: You referred the plan having been generated by the City Council would you tell us exactly how that happened step by step?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.
The process was, on the 17th of January, the Court held the original plan unconstitutional.
Three days later the City Council adopted a resolution which informed the Court that it was the intent of the council to pass an ordinance which would adopt this eight/three plan.
On February the 5th, the Court commenced hearings on this proposed eight/three plan and on two alternate plans submitted by the plaintiffs in the case.
On the 8th of February the district judge announced a preliminary finding that he considered the eight/three plan to be constitutional.
Two days later, after the conclusion of that hearing, the City Council adopted the Ordinance 14800 which promulgated as law, the eight/three plan.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: The City Council had not adopted the plan until after the Court approved the plan that was suggested?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: That is correct, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Except by a resolution?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Except by resolution.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, The City Council did it though, did it not?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It just was not in the form of an ordinance?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: That is correct, sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Is the resolution in the record?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, if that had been an ordinance, it might as well have been an ordinance?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Well, I think if it had been an ordinance, there would not be any question at this point.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But why should there be any difference?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Well, I think in fairness to the respondents in this case, there is some ambiguity in the resolution.
I think it clearly indicates that what the legislative body favored was the eight/three plan.
However, the resolution --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I thought that is what the City Council was proposing?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That was clear enough.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: But let me ask you this question, did the City Council have any power or authority to approve a plan definitively?
Did it not have to be submitted to the voters?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Mr. Justice Powell, what we had here was a previous plan prescribed by a charter.
Now, obviously the charter, somewhat like our city constitution, cannot be amended except by vote of the people.
However, after the district judge --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Or an order of the Court?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

After the order of district court declaring it unconstitutional in that charter provision our position has ceased to exist and we have the authority as a Home Rule of city under the laws of Texas to evidence our actions either by resolution by ordinance or by vote of the people in the form of the charter.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you might just as well have passed the ordinance when you passed the resolution, except you probably would rather know whether it was constitutional before you passed it as an ordinance?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that the explanation why the council proceeded by resolution rather than ordinance at that time?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Mr. Justice Brennan, frankly, we do not know at this point.
We cannot recall and I assume, that that is what we were doing.
If we had the benefit of Chapman v. Meier, which was decided within a few days --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What if it had been an ordinance when the resolution was passed?
What if it had been done in the form of an ordinance?
The district court would have done exactly the same thing with respect to it?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir, I think it would have and I think, if it had been passed as an ordinance a few days before the hearing then there would be no question that the city had promulgated this plan as law and then it was binding.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Werner, the question I am now going to ask you is not addressed to merits in this case, but you filed an application for a stay with me last August, at least your name is on it, and it states the City Council reapportioned itself, enacted an ordinance and thereafter that the Court held hearing, now that is an error, I take it from what you now say?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Mr. Justice Powell, if I said that I have misled the Court and you, sir...

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I think, I repeated it in the Chambers opinion and I will say this in fairness, the district courts said pretty much the same thing, but I now understand from the facts that is not what happened.

I am not suggesting that it makes any difference that Mr. Justice White indicates, but I do suggest that the papers filed here, and while I am on this subject, I must say that the response to your application did not clarify it either.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Powell, what happened here was that on the 8th of February there was no order entered and the docket does not reflect any order, what happened was the judge made a preliminary finding that he considered the eight/three plan to be acceptable.

There was no written order of any description entered until March 25th about six weeks later and of course, the judgment in the case was not entered until May the 22nd which was about three and a half months later so we did not consider at that point that there had been any, at that time the ordinance was adopted, we did not consider that there had been any binding order of the court.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I just want to clarify that.
I felt that I find these other papers in this case that both parties had failed adequately to inform me even this matter was before me last summer.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

If we have misled you and the Court, we apologize for that, but I think the contention between the parties has always been the authority of the city to make a change to the election plan through the means of an ordinance rather than by a charter amendment and I do not think at that time any of the parties considered the timing of this ordinance to be critical and I do not think we considered that the ordinance was adopted after an order of the Court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now you are confusing me.
You have spoken of it previously as a resolution not an ordinance.
Now, which was the source of the new eight/three plan?
A resolution or an ordinance?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Well, Mr. Chief Justice, they were both.
On the 20th of January before the remedy hearing, there was a resolution passed stating the intention of the council to adopt the eight/three plan.
Then the remedy hearing was held in the District Court and then two days after the conclusion of that hearing the ordinance was passed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And that was pursuant to the directives of the Court?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: No, sir, there was no directive from the Court that we pass an ordinance.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the Court addressed itself to the plans submitted by the city under the resolution and said it was constitutional?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, did it purport to treat that as a court plan and say, I approve this plan, or did they, you know, usually if the city passes an ordinance it is not a court plan, it is just something you either accept or reject.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What did the Court do with respect to the resolution?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir, on February the 8th at the conclusion of the hearing, Judge Mahon, the District Judge, made a rather lengthy statement from the bench in which he said that he finds the eight/three plan, in his words, Passes constitutional muster, and he said he would later issue an opinion.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He has (Voice Overlap) that plan in a decree?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.
The first writing from the Court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: When you do not do that with an ordinance, that you uphold, you just say it is constitutional and you look to the ordinance to see what the provisions are.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: I may have misunderstood your question, Mr. Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did he incorporate the very terms of the plan in the decree?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: No, sir, only by saying that he found that it was constitutional.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That it was constitutional?
Okay.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then when he approved the eight/three plan, it was simply a holding of the Court that it passed constitutional standards, but it is not part of a decree?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: No, sir.
And there was no written order of any description entered until long after the ordinance was enacted.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I think I have the mind of the District Court that Mr. Justice White may have in mind, it is on page B 16 in the petition at the end of the middle paragraph.
That is B 16.
This Court then gave the city of Dallas an opportunity to perform its duty to enact a constitutionally acceptable plan.
I find that it has met that duty in enacting the eight/three plan of electing council members.
Now in light of what I now understand, the Court, to say the least, used the word enacting somewhat loosely.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The resolution expressing an intent.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir, and then --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He interpreted it as an official expression of the court.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then after this decree it was followed by an ordinance, and that in turn was followed by a charter amendment.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: That is my understanding,

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir, that is correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Werner, is that quite correct.
Was it not true that there was oral opinion first which was then followed by the ordinance, which was then followed what Mr. Justice Powell just read?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Mr. Justice Stevens, there was the resolution, then --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: On January 20th.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And then on February 8th there was the remedy hearing?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In which he made an oral decision?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And then there was an ordinance, which is number 14800, which refers back to the oral decision, is that not right?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And then after the ordinance was passed, there was then the written decision that Mr. Justice Powell read from in March.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of March 25.

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, March 25th.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is where he used the word 'enacted'

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So this is after the ordinance, whereas the oral decision was between the resolution and the ordinance?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The enactment is the ordinance?
What is the word enactment there?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Well, I think the reference is to the ordinance, but I cannot be certain what he meant.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: By this time there was an ordinance?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if I am not correct, Mr. Werner, at the time of the ordinance, there had already been a decision by the Court because the ordinance itself refers to the decision and I call you attention to page A 2 of the --

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: Yes sir, it refers to the oral decision and if I may, I will read from the transcript of the judge?s remarks, this is volume 11 of the original transcript, page 86, the Court says, ?This Court has accepting --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do we have it in print here at all?

turn.speaker: joseph_g_werner
turn.label: Mr. Joseph G. Werner
turn.text: No, sir, it is not reproduced in the appendix.
The district judge says, This Court is accepting the city plan of eight/three.
I am ordering that the election schedule for April of this year will proceed and elect the City Council for this year under the city plan of eight/three that has been presented to this Court.
At the same time, this Court will, I am going to enter a final order, I mean an adjustment in the opinion that is going to take me several days, and so forth.
So he indicated at that time that it seems to us that this was a tentative or preliminary decision on the matter and that he intended shortly thereafter to render his official decision on the case.

Now, Mr. Chief Justice and May it please the Court, it is our position that at the time that the Court first entered a written order in its first binding order that the City Council had already promulgated as law this eight/three plan which is in contention.

By the time the filing date arrived for the ensuing election, the plan had been promulgated as law, and by the time the judgment was finally entered in case, of course, the plan had been promulgated as law by the City Council.

We contend that because the council had promulgated as law this election plan with full authority under state law that this is not a court order plan and that the special circumstances rule of the East Carroll case should not apply.
We suggest instead that the rule of Burns v. Richardson applies and that the plan should be subject only to constitutional review.

Alternatively, we submit to the Court, that even if the East Carroll rule is applicable, that the Court of Appeals has erred in saying that the special circumstances present in the case which deal with the voting situation of Mexican-American voters can be considered only if there is a constitutional violation and we think that this is contrary to indications that we see in the opinion in the United U.S. Organizations v. Carrie case.

We do not think that special circumstances in a case like this depend on a prior showing of a constitutional violation and we think that in this case as in any equitable case or decree in equity that the Court should take into consideration the general public interest and should not enter a decree which will harm any segment of the population and we think that the findings of the District Court show that if and all single member district plan were put into effect that the Mexican-American voters would very definitely harmed by that decree.

The other issue in the case which supports the use of a mixed at-large and single member system is the finding of the District Court that it would be beneficial to the city to have general citywide interest represented on the council so as to provide factionalism among wards within the city and so that the City Council members would be exposed to a more statesmanlike view and that projects of interest to the city in general would not suffer from having been subjected to ward interest and the factionalism.
May it please the Court, we will reserve the rest of our time for rebuttal.

section.heading: Argument of James A. Johnston, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Werner.
Mr. Johnston.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
It is the contention of respondents here today that this Court is dealing with the fact situation that is clearly within the ambit of Connor v. Johnson and East Carroll Parish v. Marshall.

We believe that the threshold issue is the standard of review that is to be applied by an appeals court and that that standard of review is determined by whether or not we are dealing with a court ordered plan or a legislated plan.

It is our contention that we have here is very clearly a court ordered plan, that is a plan that was ordered into existence by Federal Court exercising its equitable jurisdiction in an adversary proceeding.
Now, there is some ambiguity in the record as it is presented in the appendix and I would like to address myself to that at this time.
Your questionings already have indicated some elements of that ambiguity.
I would point out on page 147 of the appendix, that the Court itself stated that at the close of testimony on February 8th, 1975, I made findings which approved the city?s plan as constitutional.
Accordingly, I order that the eight/three plan as had been offered by the city be instituted in time for the April 1975 City Council election.
Let me point out that at this point that the City Council does not either by resolution or by ordinance have the power to change the election system in the city of Dallas.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Johnston, does it have authority by resolution to empower its legal counsel to make representations to the District Court in a case like this?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: It can and did empower its legal representatives to make representations to the Court and I have here and can supply to the court a copy of the accompanying letter that counsel for the city sent to the Court and that accompanying letter said, Pursuant to your order issued January 17th, I am enclosing a certified copy of the Dallas City Council resolution dated January 20.
I think what is clear here is that this resolution was offered pursuant to an order of the court to offer.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, that sounds like we are going back to the forms of action to make this sort of distinction between a court saying we will impose a plan, but let us hear from the city as to what kind of a plan it wants and saying that that is subject to a different standard of scrutiny than for the court to say the present plan is unconstitutional let the city try again?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: I think the distinction has to be made as to whether or not the city has the authority to try again under its own legislative scheme.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why is that for a Federal Court to decide?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: We are talking about legislative power and the constitution of the State of Texas denies to the City Council the right to change its election scheme.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I do not see why we are talking about legislative power, we are trying to decide what standards the District Court is supposed to use and here this is an unambiguous expression of the lawmakers? views of the city of Dallas.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: The courts had before it in the East Carroll the same kind of unambiguous statement of what the city would choose and the same in Wallace v. Brown.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I think it is a District Court that rejected the plan as unconstitutional and proceeded to draw up its own, might be something else again or if the city lawyer had just submitted the plan without any evidence that it was official policy of the city?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: The case laws at this point would indicate that this Court has been looking as in East Carroll to the authority of the city to reorganize its legislation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you would say if the city had had power to change and represent this scheme overnight by an ordinance and if their first action in response to the Court's suggestion had to pass a new ordinance, the case would be different, you say?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: The case would be different, I would still urge the same result because we are dealing with a plan that was offered up after the fact of dilution of black voting streams, that finding had already made by it the Trial Court.
We are not talking about a situation where in the course of litigation the city changes its election --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, That sounds to me like you are urging that the substitute plan offered was unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: No, we are saying only at this point that it violates the federal common law of voting rights.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You do not mean the common law of voting rights, do you?
You mean the appropriate equitable remedy for violation of the constitution?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That language is not my own, it appears in --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I would adopt it if I were you, it is not --
You do not find it in our cases, do you?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So we are talking the precedents to which you refer and upon which you rely, have to do what is appropriate and an equitable remedy to repair a constitutional violation and the cases to which you refer all involve violations of the doctrine of Reynolds v. Sims not a single one of them that I know of involved a violation of such as was found here which we do not have before us, and therefore, we cannot assess as to even whether or not it was a constitutional violation, but there is no claim that there was a violation of the so called one person, one vote?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And indeed all the cases to which you refer, none of them with which I am familiar and you are free to correct me, I may be wrong, I often am, have to do with at-large municipal elections of councilmen and there has been a presumption in this case that multi...member districts to a state legislature are somehow the exact equivalent of at-large elections in a municipality to the city government and they are quite two different animals.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Let me respond, if I may.
In East Carroll Parish v. Marshall, it began in the context of a Baker v. Carroll, one man, one vote case.
However, when the Court approved, the Parishes posed all at-large plan in 1971, Mr. Marshall intervened alleging that that plan diluted black voting strength in the parish.

The District Court rejected that finding, but it was preserved for appeal to the Court of Appeals and the Court of Appeals found in fact that there had been a dilution of black voting strength as alleged by Mr. Marshall and so when that case, East Carroll was before this Court, it was before this Court on that basis as well as on the one man, one vote analysis.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It did involve a school district but it did not involve a Home Rule municipality, did it?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor, but the fact that the City of Dallas is a Home Rule city should not overlook the fact that it is limited in its ability to devise its own election scheme.
It must submit that to --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, but I am talking about the constitutional test here and the remedy for asserted constitutional violation.
This violation was not a Reynolds v. Sims violation and we are not talking here about multi member districts to state legislatures.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct, but it would seem to me that the federal remedy which we urge and which East Carroll urges which would require single member districts absent unusual circumstances it is particularly appropriate when there was a finding by the District Court as a result of an adversary proceeding that the at-large features of the City of Dallas election system diluted black minority voting strength.
For the city to come back with three at-large seats preserving that same feature found unconstitutional which seemed to me --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It is assuredly that is a given in this case, but in assessing this plan do we not again have to look and see whether an at-large election is unconstitutional, is it not the least the threshold inquiry?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: The District Court had already made findings --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Oh, but District Court did, you are here now.
But you are here now and if there is nothing at all unconstitutional about at-large elections in a municipality of the governing body of the city, that is the end of this case, is it not?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court wishes to address itself to that issue, it may do so --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is a threshold issue here.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: No one else, certainly petitioners have not raised that issue and did not appeal in either court --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They certainly raised it to the extent that they say that the at-large election of three members of the City Council is not unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct and I would point out to the Court that Wallace v. House had dealt with a commissioner form of a government for a city and that is a case where the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit as in this case had to address itself with that issue.
This Court remanded that case to the Fifth Circuit for a review in light of East Carroll Parish.

The circuit examined the entire record and examined the contentions very much like the cities here that at-large elections preserved a city wide view and rejected that as having established any kind of unusual circumstances.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Has this Court ever held that an at-large election, within a jurisdiction is unconstitutional, be it city or state?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: I think Wallace v. House tacitly reaches that point because it goes immediately to the remedy.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But those were all based on one man, one vote violation, now you get to the remedial phase, were they not?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: It is not my understanding that Wallace is based on one man, one vote.
My reflection on the record in that case indicates that there was an allegation of and a finding in the Fifth Circuit that there was dilution of --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That is not exactly one man, one vote, Whitcomb v. Chavez certainly rejects any notion that at-large voting in the city is per se or even semi per se, in doubt.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct, but it does indicate that if the proof is there and White v. Regester goes farther than that and says that the proof was there in that circumstance then you have established a constitutional violation of equal protection.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But one of the original complaints in Whitcomb v. Chavez was not the multi member district's violated the constitution, but that there was a violation of one man, one vote principle, was there not and then the question was whether the remedy was appropriate?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: I cannot recall the record of it at that point.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let me back up on one thing that has left me somewhat confused.

Suppose Judge Mahon, the district judge, had after asking the city to make suggestions and the city made no suggestions, he had ordered the eight/three plan and they carried it out without a resolution, without an ordinance, simply carrying out the court's decree, what would be your view of what effect that would have on your posture now?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Well, our posture would be the same, that it was in fact a court ordered plan --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: For all practical purposes, it was a court ordered plan, was it not and the city was, simply as a matter of comity or for whatever reasons, passing an enactment that carried out what they knew the Court wanted and what the Court had said would pass constitutional muster?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: And what the Court would require as a remedy.
We have no objections as such and did not object at that time to the city offering to the Court a plan.
There is political expertise to be had amongst members of the City Council and although their vote was not unanimous, their input was important and we did not object to it as such.
What we did object to, what we did appeal from was preserving those same at-large features that the Court had rejected in finding that there was dilution of black voting strength.
Now, it is not easy to prove that there has been dilution of black voting strength by means of at-large elections.
The proof is not simple, but it was met in this case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It is particularly difficult, is it not when you have an eight/three plan that is eight of them elected by districts and only three at-large, two at-large, really, because one of them is the mayor.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That is why I think that the remedy required by East Carroll is particularly appropriate in these kind of cases because it instructs the city or whoever is working with the Court in order to purpose a plan that they must do several things and one of those things is that they must establish that there are unusual circumstances which will justify the continuation of any at-large features in that plan.
It is particularly appropriate in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We would not suggest for a moment in the course of this case that whatever stage it was that the city, let us assume that the City Council of Dallas had the power in its charter to pass a new ordinance, it just simply passed a new ordinance and the old ordinance that the Court was considering just was not there anymore.
The ordinance would either go into effect, it would not going into effect unless it was enjoined and found unconstitutional, would it not?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Well, of course that is not the facts before us now, but --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I know you say it is not the facts --

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Well, one would have to and I presume, one would seek some sort of injunctive relief from --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But then you would have to submit that ordinance to the Court and that ordinance would have to be found unconstitutional before it could be enjoined and I understand the Fifth Circuit in this case says that this ordinance is not unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: The Fifth Circuit in this case never reached that issue and did not speak to that issue at all.
It said that that was one of things that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The District Court certainly did, did it not?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: The District Court certainly did.
Let me point out --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I think there was no unconstitutional impact whatsoever under this.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct and let me point out the difficulties that anyone litigating a plan in a hurry where we have an election coming up in April and we were in February, we spent five years attempting to prove the unconstitutionality of the eleven at-large seats in city of Dallas.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Exactly, and the city came along and passed a new ordinance.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Let me point out that the city and I think this is instructive.

We have supplied the Court with a copy of the ballot that was used in April of 1976, when the voters finally ratified that ordinance and finally amended the charter with regard to the change in election scheme and that ballot on page 16 of the document we supplied the Court which begins with the letter from Mr. Werner to an attorney in town, and it says, Charter chapter 3, section 1 and chapter 4 section 4, 6, and 8 of the charter of the city of Dallas be amended to provide for the compliance with the federal court order for election of eight members to the City Council from single member districts and three, including the mayor at-large.

We think that is instructive because it indicates what that the city believed as we believe that that election that took place in April of 1976 was a housekeeping measure merely to reflect the changes that were already made by court order in the city charter.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Johnston, was is it part of your submission in opposing the eight/three ordinance, that it was unconstitutional or did you merely argue that it was an inadequate remedy for the previously found constitutional violation?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Our argument, essentially, was that it was an inadequate remedy.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So that there really has never been an issue that anybody has had to decide as to whether the eight/three order was constitutional or unconstitutional, is that correct?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: The judge presumed that if it were constitutional --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It would be an adequate remedy.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: It would be inadequate remedy, although I may point out that the judge was troubled by Connor v. Johnson and throughout his opinion attempted to state unusual circumstances such as the Mexican-American situation which would justify the plan, but we were not anywhere equipped to argue the constitutionality of that plan because that kind of proof is very difficult to come by in the short space of time that we had.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If the fact or the conclusion of constitutionality were the end of the case, he would not have needed even to address the question of the Mexican-Americans, is that not correct?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

Let me also point out that as the government has pointed out in its brief amicus that when this charter amendment was passed in April of 1976, Texas was at that time covered by the Voting Rights Act of 1965, something that it was not covered when the case was tried and the decision was rendered in 1975 and the city did not submit that case to the Attorney General for pre-clearance.
The inference is that the city believed that plan to be a court ordered plan which was not required to be submitted to the Attorney General under the Court's language in Connor v. Johnson.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: District Court said that it gave the city a chance to come up with a plan and he said, "I find that it has met that duty in enacting the eight/three plan of electing council members."

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: The judges opinion is ambiguous in several respects.
In that way it is ambiguous because the Court later on points out on page 151 of the appendix that the members of the council cannot on their own modify the charter to alter the voting scheme.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that may be so, but this seems to me rather unambiguous in saying that in his view, the plan wherever it came from passed constitutional muster.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think that it is clear in the Court's belief --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And do you not believe that the intervenors in that were urging that the plan was unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: I think that is correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And so there was an issue before the judge about the constitutionality of the plan?
He just did not arrive at this conclusion sua sponte?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I can only respond that the Court was, as were the parties, operating under intense time pressure --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, it may be, but the intervenors claimed it was unconstitutional and he said the plan is constitutional and did you appeal that?
When you went to the Fifth Circuit what did you say to them?
What did you raise there?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the issue that we raised in the fifth circuit was the appropriateness of the remedy.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And did you say the plan was unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That appeal was some years ago, I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, here is what the Fifth Circuit said, It cannot, however, be successfully maintained that the use of at-large voting to select three council members is itself constitutionally defective.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct and there is plenty of language from this court indicating that at-large features in and off themselves must be attacked on the factual matrix in which they develop.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is multi member districts for a state legislative body?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I would say that Wallace v. House and then applying it to the parish as in East Carroll indicates the court is willing to go further than that.
On this subject, let me conclude by saying that it is very difficult --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You have referred counsel several times to Wallace v. House, that is not a case of this court, is it?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, it is.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: We remanded it for consideration.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: You remanded it for consideration in light of East Carroll.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is the extent of its --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But it is not a decision on the merits by this court?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Well, to the extent that the Court of Appeals took it to mean that what was involved was the East Carroll issue which is a one issue case, essentially.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, then it is certainly a decision of the Court of Appeals to that effect, but not a decision of this Court to that effect?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I would only say, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, that the clear implication of the remand of Wallace v. House was that what the Court of Appeals must consider was the appropriateness of the remedy.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Exactly, and of course, the Court of Appeals did do that and cert was denied by this Court.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But do you think all of our remands are that precisely tailored, that we never grant, vacate and remand except having thought the thing through that carefully?
That is not a fair question to ask you.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I think it is very fair.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: A remand is a question not an answer.
If we were sure of the application, we would summarily decide the case, but if not being clear, we send it back and ask the Court of Appeals to consider the relevance of East Carroll and others.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the Court of Appeals did reconsider.

It asked itself the question of why the case was remanded rather than simply reversed or affirmed and concluded that the appropriateness of the remedy under East Carroll was a factual and that they could undertake it because they had a complete record before them and they undertook at that point to determine whether or not they were unusual circumstances, found that there were not in the face of claims much like the city of Dallas here, and as I --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And then did it not come back here again?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: It did and certiorari was denied, that is correct.
I find it difficult to distinguish this case from East Carroll and from Wallace v. House, all the cases that have gone through the Court of Appeals of the Fifth Circuit.

Each time there were plans submitted by the legislative body pursuant to court order each time that that legislative body lacked the authority to draw up a plan, it did not have the authority for one reason or another to implement the plan.
In East Carroll it was because of a challenge under Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act to the enabling legislation and in each case the plan was ordered into effect by the court.

Now, once you reach the threshold issue of whether or not the rule of East Carroll is going to be applied, the issue becomes whether or not there were unusual circumstances which would justify preservation of the at-large features.
The district court found such in the Mexican-American presence in the city of Dallas, a minority group containing 8-10% of the population of the city of Dallas.
The trial court's findings are confusing and contradictory and I think, ultimately not based on fact, and therefore, abuse of the discretion of the trial court.
The trial court found that there was no present delusion of Mexican-American voting strengths, although there might have been delusion in the past.

The Court of Appeals, accordingly indicated that because there was no present delusion their access was equal to that of the white majority, and therefore, there was no need to enhance the benefits by these three at-large seats.

But more importantly it's contention of the respondents that in order for there to be an unusual circumstance to support the Mexican-American issue raised by the district court there would have to be facts in the record to support a finding that single member districts would restrict the access of Mexican-American voters and there are no such findings in the record.
In fact, the district court could only conclude that Mexican-American voters might suffer restriction and access under the single member district plan.

The record that we presented to the court indicates that in a single member district plan such as the ones we proposed, a district, district number two would contain approximately one third of Mexican-American population and as such, Mexican-Americans practicing the politics of coalition as the Court of Appeals called it would have a far greater input into the election of members of the council than they would when they comprised only 8-10% of the population.

In fact, we presented to the court a witness, a Mexican-American by the name of Robert Madrano, who had run at-large for a school board seat and lost and then when they changed to an all single member district plan had won in a seat that was approximately evenly divided between Blacks, Mexican-American, and White voters, therefore demonstrating and the only factual demonstration in the record that Mexican-Americans could in fact win in single member district circumstances.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, does that prove any more than what has been said in some opinions of the courts that people do not necessarily indulge always in block voting?
If they find a candidate attractive, they will vote for him as such, that is what indicates the reason for a half a dozen Negro mayors in the United States in large cities, does it not?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: It does not, in fact, Mr. Chief Justice, it helps --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: For the man, not on a racial basis.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: However, the record as developed in the trial of this cause from every expert witness indicates that in the city of Dallas, we have the unfortunate situation where block voting along racial lines is the rule and anything else is the exception.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The record also shows that when the primary case was won on April 14th, in 1944, all of the Negroes in Dallas were the solid block and by election time they had split into four different groups, that is what the records show, four groups and that was about five months.

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: The record will also show in this case that since the institution of the eight/three plan ordered by the district court, there has not been a Mexican-American candidate elected to the City Council in the city of Dallas. Previously there had been one, but since this time, although they have run, I do not believe, I think the record will indicate that, none of them have won more than a third of the vote, and therefore, have failed in their efforts to be elected at-large.

The court itself acknowledged in its opinion that at-large voting might operate in part as a restriction of the access of American voters and we think there is simply no evidence to support them as unusual circumstances.

Finally, let me address briefly the issue of whether or not a city wide viewpoint can also be an unusual circumstance. I point to the Court's opinion in last time Connor v. Finch where this Court indicated that historic policy in multi member districts was not a sufficient reason to uphold multi member districts and in Wallace v. House itself the Court of Appeals originally attempted to justify a single at-large seat among five on grounds that they were avoiding ward parochialism, a contention subsequently rejected on remand.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Johnston, was Connor v. Finch a City Council or a legislative apportion?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: It was legislative apportion.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is there not a fair amount of expertise in city management and city government to the effect that strictly election by ward does tend to lead to pork barreling in a way that it does not on a state wide basis?

turn.speaker: james_a_johnston
turn.label: Mr. James A. Johnston, Jr.
turn.text: If there is such study, it was not in evidence in this case.
That was asserted by some politicians who had been elected at-large.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Buscemi.

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
I would like to begin by saying that I think that Mr. Justice Stewart is correct in suggesting that this Court has never found at-large municipal elections to be unconstitutional.

This Court in East Carroll Parish School Board v. Marshall, however, did find that the district court in ordering at-large elections, not only the East Carroll Parish School Board, but also for the parish jury which is the local legislative body had violated the remedial principles that this court has set out in numerous reapportionment cases, all of them beginning with one man, one vote violations.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: As this one did not.

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: As this one did not, that is right.

In addition to the East Carroll case this Court has recognized in Duch v. Davis and in Dallas County, Alabama v. Reese that there is the possibility that at-large municipal elections, local elections, either county or city, may result in the minimization or the canceling out, to use the court's words, of the votes of particular, identifiable minority groups.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that is always true when you have an election by majority rule.
If municipality is 55% democratic, the votes of the republicans are going to be canceled out in at-large election.

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: That is true and that is what the basis of the Courts holding was in Whitcomb v. Chaviz where the Court found that there was no restriction of access by Blacks to the political process, but the Blacks were primarily democrats, there were lots of republicans in Indiana and the republicans won a lot of elections and as the consequence of that there were very few Blacks that were elected to the state legislature from Marion County, Indiana, but that is not what the district court found in this case and I think the evidence supports the findings of the district court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Do you not think there is a difference, at least from the point of view of political structure and political science between a board of county commissioners or a county jury or whatever it may be called in various states, the school board on the same side on the one hand, and a small City Council elected at-large with the city manager system in a Home Rule municipality on the other?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Stewart, there may very well be a difference there and we are not contending and the respondents are not contending -

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And why should the same, if there is a difference, why should the same constitutional rule, at least why should it automatically be transferred from one to the other?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, this case as it stands now it does not really involve the constitutional rule.
We are talking about a remedy that has been --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, at least at the threshold, it involves whether at-large municipal elections are, if there is any defect in them at all, does it not?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, that is true and the district court found that in the circumstances --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The District Court found so.

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: In Dallas there was a defect.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Electing eleven of them at-large, now whether or not that is right or wrong is not now before us, as I understand it, but certainly that at the threshold there is before us the question of whether the election of three members of the council, including the mayor at-large is defective in any respect?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: That is right.
This Court need not find that the election of three council members at-large is unconstitutional --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, if it is undesirable, as a matter of view of a remedy, is that not the threshold consideration?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: That is right and this Court has said, admittedly in one man, one vote cases that reapportionment should prefer single member districts and that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And never said so with respect to a city managed municipality, never, is it?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Not in the context of at-large dilution.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No, or in any context, has it?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, in East Carroll for example --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But that is not a city manager municipality, is it?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: No, it is a parish police jury.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Your position is that even though we were to conclude if presented with the issue on the merits that an eleven man at-large City Council would not be unconstitutional, the district court simply should dismiss the complaint, in this case we should nevertheless affirm the Fifth Circuit which held that three at-large members were improper remedially?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, I think that the only issue before the Court is whether the remedy was improper.

Now, as Mr. Justice Stewart suggests, if the court finds that at-large elections may be ordered as a remedy because the Court does not believe that there is any constitutional violation involved in all eleven being elected at-large then presumably, the Court would not need to affirm, but our suggestion here is that the violation that was found was indeed a violation and that the appropriate remedy for a Court ordered reapportionment plan involves single member districts.

Now, as the district court pointed out, Dallas is completely free to present the eight/three plan to the district court for the District of Columbia or to the Attorney General for pre-clearance under Section 58 of the Voting Rights Act and then, if the plan is pre-cleared, it will go into effect and any Court ordered remedy for the constitutional violation found will be over.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: After a District Court orders it, are you suggesting that it must be pre-cleared, that the judges order must be pre-cleared?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: No, not at all.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, is it not the judges order?
Is this not the judges plan?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Right now, this is a court ordered plan, that is right.
We are suggesting that the court --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then why is it subject to Section 5 then?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: We are saying that as a court ordered plan it is defective because it departs from the remedial principles announced by this court in earlier cases.
We are saying that if Dallas wishes to have this plan --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, Dallas did not wish to have it, the court imposed it on them, Dallas did not want it at all?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: That is true, but Dallas now says that it wants the eight/three plan and if --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, if it wants it, something as though after it is ordered by this Court, they might want it, but they did not want it in the first place, they have it because the court ordered it, have they not?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: That is true and indeed Dallas --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well then why does Section 6 get into the act?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well because if Dallas now wants the eight/three plan or if Dallas wants the seven/four plan or indeed, if Dallas wants two single member districts and nine members elected at-large, they are free to submit that plan to the district court in the District of Columbia.
They did not challenge the finding of unconstitutionality.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Suppose we do not agree with you that it is a court order plan?
Suppose we view the resolution as such as a legislative plan?
Would it now require Section 5 clearance?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It would, even though it became such before Texas became a covered jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What authority is the reason for that?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Section 5 provides that the city may not enact or seek to administer any plan not in effect on November 1, 1972.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then is it your submission that if this is a legislative and not a court ordered plan, nevertheless there has to be an affirmance because there has not been a pre-clearance?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: That is right?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean Texas, when it was covered should have gone back and submitted every, when was it covered, 1972?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: September 18, 1975.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: 1975, so it should have gone back and canvassed all the changes that had ever been made since 1972 and submitted them all to the Attorney General?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Yes, but indeed, no changes had been made since 1972.
The at-large elections --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Anywhere in Texas?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How can you know that in a state like Texas?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, I am talking about in Dallas.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I am putting to you the question was Texas.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Your proposition was the whole state.

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: That is right, if there have been changes --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Anywhere in Texas, locally, statewide, any change in the great state of Texas, you are supposed to bundle them up in a bushel basket and take them all to the Attorney General?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: The ones that were not in effect on November 1, 1972.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And did they do that?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Has all of Texas done it or did Dallas do it?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Any of them.
Does the Attorney General attempted to find out if they ever did it or you just wait for complaints?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, we wait for submissions.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right, very good.
Let me see, like in Perkins, I think the Court held even a change of location of ballots, of polling places required pre-clearance.

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you not suppose since 1972, there have been changes of polling places in the state of Texas?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: I am sure they have and I am sure many of those have not been submitted and I am sure that the Attorney General has not exercised his right under the statute of to bring a private enforcement suits.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But perhaps elections based on the changes in the polling places may now be challenged because of failure to get a pre-clearance?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, I do not think that the change in polling place itself would be --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Has there ever been a court decision that the Section 5 is retroactive like that or do you just read it on its face?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, I think that when Section 5 was initially --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And it is possible to interpret it, I suppose, as meaning that any change hereafter that was not in effect in 1972?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, any change hereafter by definition would not have been in effect on November 1, 1972.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, all right, but has there been some court decisions on this retroactivity?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, I am not sure whether there were any.
When the Voting Rights Act was originally enacted, it was passed on August 6, 1975, but it referred to changes that had taken place since November 1, 1964.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Have there been some submissions from Texas since it was included based on the fact that this particular practice that is now being administered was instituted in 1973 and is still being administered and --

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Not that I know of.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So it has never even been construed by the Attorney General, until now?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: I think that if there had been such a submission, the Attorney General would have reviewed it under Section 5.
I just want to comment briefly on the special circumstances that were noted by the district court.
First of all those circumstances were noted in the context of an evaluation of the constitutionality of the eight/three plan.

The district court never said that it was talking about special circumstances or unusual situations that this Court has referred in speaking of departures from the single member district preference in court ordered remedies.

The district court did not make such a finding and indeed the special circumstances decided by the district court in connection with its assessment of the plan?s constitutionality are far different from the special circumstances noted by this Court on the only occasion when this Court approved multi-member districts in a court ordered plan and that was in Mahan v. Howell where it had a very special situation involving the Norfolk Naval Base.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Do you think it makes any difference in this connection between a city such as Dallas which has had at-large voting since 1907 and the parish in Louisiana that had had at-large voting only since 1968?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, I think that may very well make a difference with respect to whether at-large voting is useful in the city or whether it is constitutional.
I do not think it should make a difference on what a court ordered reapportionment plan should involve.
I think that this Court in Chapman v. Meier spoke about the long time use of at-large elections and suggested that --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: No, I think Chapman v. Meier of South Dakota --

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: North Dakota.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: North Dakota, well, did not the court say that Mr. Justice Blackmun would correct me that there had been no tradition in --

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: In the senate, in the North Dakota senate.
The court did comment, however, that there had been a tradition of at-large, that are multi member districts in the North Dakota House of Representatives.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: But not in the Senate.

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And the Court made a point of that?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will resume at 1 o'clock.

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have some rebuttal.
I think you have one minute remaining, Mr. Buscemi.

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

During luncheon recess I have obtained some information on the Court's question on the applications of the Voting Rights Act to the State of Texas and the changes that have occurred between November 1972 and September 1975.
The Attorney General has received hundreds of submissions involving such changes both in Texas itself and from localities within the state.
Some of those changes we are informed, did involve changes in polling place locations to answer Mr. Justice Brennan?s question.
Indeed, during the twelve months immediately following the application of the Voting Rights Act to Texas, more submissions were received from that one state alone.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I do not doubt it.

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: There are more of the other areas covered under the Act combined.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you still contend that this case is subject to Section 5 submission?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Well, the relevance of this point to this case is that if an ordinance, if the City Council could have under state law reapportioned itself by ordinance and if such an ordinance had been passed and if the eight/three plan was now effective by virtue of a City Council ordinance, then that ordinance would have to be submitted --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, Mr. Buscenmi, why did you not answer the Chief Justice 'Yes'?
Merely from that fact that it was April 1976 after the 1975 coverage that the ordinance finally became legal when it was approved into referendum and did not become effective until then.
Then certainly why can you not answer the Chief Justice Of course the eight/three plan has to have pre-clearance under Section 5?

turn.speaker: peter_buscemi
turn.label: Mr. Peter Buscemi
turn.text: Absolutely, that is the answer to the Chief Justice?s question to the extent that there is a legislatively enacted plan involved here, it is only through the charter amendment that was passed in April 1976 and that is what we argued in the second part --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
